Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Sensory System for Autonomous Area-Wide Disease and Agriterror Detection and Reporting
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II research project will fabricate nanosensory arrays using the Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) technique. This electrochemical polymerization of biomolecule-friendly conducting polymers was developed and successfully tested to build functional, highly reliable nanosensors. This research will address key technical challenges in automating the fabrication of antibody-functionalized conducting nanowires that are individually addressable and scalable to high-density biosensor arrays for the detection of Huanglongbing (HLB). The resultant nanosensory-arrays will form the base for the development of small, effective, inexpensive, field worthy, autonomous and automated pathogen detection devices. These units will permit the unattended processing of a large number of field samples, thus increasing the temporal and geographical density of data collection, providing superior pathogen and agri-terror detection.

Current disease management techniques typically lack the data collection technologies needed to avert epidemics; diagnostic instruments are not amenable to unattended autonomous operation. Devices currently used are slow, expensive, bulky, and must interface with humans. Consequently, only few pathogen introductions are detected before causing widespread disease or epidemics. This research will increase the efficiency in detection of plant pathogens and agents of disease, allowing for preventative rather than crisis or remedial control actions. The development of this automated system can mitigate the estimated $300 billion loss due to agricultural pests.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current disease management techniques typically lack the data collection technologies needed to avert epidemics. Diagnostic instruments are not amenable to unattended, autonomous operation, and tend to be slow, expensive, bulky, and lack the capacity for field use. Consequently, only a handful of pathogen introductions are detected before causing widespread disease outbreaks. This situation is true for diseases that impact humans directly as well as agricultural commodities.

The goal of this project was to develop new methods for increasing efficiency in detection of plant pathogens and agents of disease (typically insect vectors), allowing for preventative rather than crisis or remedial control actions. The system developed is an autonomous pest (vector and pathogen) detection and monitoring system that will allow the creation of area-wide networks to constantly monitor the presence and density of organisms of interest in the environment. The field component of this system consists of an insect Smart Trap performing the dual functions of monitoring and sample collection. The device is able to register trap counts and wirelessly transmit monitoring data that can be accessed and managed over the internet. Additionally, captured insects can be treated as biological samples for in-field pathogen detection. Through a novel application of nanosensor technology, we can create antibody-functionalized sensors able to detect the presence of corresponding antigens present in biological samples (insect or plant material).

Citrus greening disease was selected as a model for demonstrating the efficacy of the system. This disease is caused by a bacterium that is vectored by the Asian citrus psyllid. Psyllids transmit the bacterium to citrus trees during feeding, resulting in an incurable condition that ultimately leads to the death of the plant. The only effective methods of control are early detection and removal of infected trees combined with management of the psyllid vector to limit the spread of the bacterium. Using newly developed experimental antibodies for detection of the citrus greening bacterium, we were able to create bionanosensors capable of detecting the disease in infected leaf tissue samples. These results were available within a matter of minutes thanks to the highly sensitive nature of the nanomaterials used. In addition, measurements can be made directly in the field using a hand-held device to quickly analyze samples collected in monitoring traps.

As research and development efforts continue, new trap components will be developed to further automate the data collection and synthesis processes. Additional pathogen complexes are already being tested with the goal of extending the system’s usefulness into other markets.
